title: REFACTOR: InMemoryRateLimiter memory optimization
description: Additional optimizations after expired entry cleanup fix. Improve cleanup efficiency and add monitoring capabilities.
design: Consider implementing: sliding window counters instead of fixed windows, probabilistic rate limiting for high-throughput, memory usage metrics, and configurable cleanup intervals.
acceptance_criteria:
- Cleanup is efficient and doesn't block requests
- Memory usage metrics are available
- Algorithm is optimized for common use cases
- All existing tests continue to pass (REFACTOR phase)
close_reason:
Implemented memory optimizations for InMemoryRateLimiter:

1. **Expiry Index with Binary Search Insertion** - O(log n) insert, O(1) to find expired entries vs O(n) full scan
2. **Batch-Limited Cleanup** - Configurable maxCleanupBatchSize prevents blocking the event loop during large cleanups
3. **Detailed Memory Metrics** - Added MemoryMetrics interface with:
   - totalEntries, entriesWithTTL, permanentEntries
   - estimatedBytes (memory usage approximation)
   - expiryIndexSize, totalCleaned, lastCleanupCount
4. **forceCleanup() Method** - For testing and immediate cleanup needs
5. **Expiry Index Compaction** - Automatically removes stale index entries

All 46 tests pass including 7 new tests for optimization features.

title: ARCH: Duplicate auth implementations in @dotdo/do and @dotdo/middleware
description:
Auth functionality is split between two packages with potential duplication:

1. `packages/do/src/auth/` - JWT validation, decorators, RBAC, session management (~60KB)
2. `packages/middleware/src/auth/` - Additional auth middleware for Hono

Issues:
- Unclear which package should own auth logic
- Potential for divergent implementations
- Middleware package barely initialized (only index.ts and placeholder dirs)

Recommendation:
1. Keep core auth logic (JWT, RBAC) in @dotdo/do
2. Make @dotdo/middleware depend on @dotdo/do for auth types
3. Middleware package provides only Hono-specific wrappers
4. Clear ownership: DO owns auth primitives, middleware owns HTTP integration
close_reason:
Consolidated auth implementations with clear ownership:

1. @dotdo/auth (packages/auth/) - Core auth primitives:
   - RBAC (roles, permissions, inheritance)
   - JWT utilities (parsing, validation, test helpers)
   - JWKS caching (instance-isolated key set caching)
   - Better Auth integration (federated auth via id.org.ai)
   - Better Auth plugins (api-key, mcp, organization, admin, oauth-proxy)

2. @dotdo/middleware-auth (middleware/auth/) - Hono HTTP integration:
   - auth() middleware (JWT/session parsing)
   - requireAuth() middleware (enforcement with roles/permissions)
   - apiKey() middleware (API key validation)
   - combined() middleware (JWT + API key fallback)

The middleware package depends on @dotdo/auth and provides Hono-specific wrappers, avoiding duplication while maintaining clear separation of concerns.

title: Magic numbers in codebase need constants
description:
Several magic numbers are scattered throughout the codebase:

1. `/packages/do/src/storage.ts` line 272: `this.maxBytes = options.maxBytes ?? 25 * 1024 * 1024` - default 25MB cache
2. `/packages/do/src/validation.ts`:
   - Line 21: `MAX_COLLECTION_LENGTH = 1000`
   - Line 26: `MAX_ID_LENGTH = 1000`
   - Line 31: `MAX_LIST_LIMIT = 100000`
   - Line 36: `MAX_QUERY_LENGTH = 10000`
3. `/packages/do/src/auth/jwt-validation.ts`:
   - Line 130: `DEFAULT_CACHE_TTL_MS = 60 * 60 * 1000` - 1 hour
   - Line 133: `NEGATIVE_CACHE_TTL_MS = 30 * 1000` - 30 seconds
4. `/packages/do/src/executor/index.ts` line 167: `timeout ?? 5000` - default 5s timeout
5. `/packages/do/src/rpc/json-rpc.ts` line 219: `maxBatchSize: options.maxBatchSize ?? 100`
6. `/packages/do/src/do.ts` line 576-577: `limit ?? 100`, `offset ?? 0` - appears in many places

**Recommended fix**: Create a central constants module with documented limits.
close_reason: Obsolete: The referenced files (/packages/do/src/storage.ts, validation.ts, auth/jwt-validation.ts, executor/index.ts, rpc/json-rpc.ts, do.ts) no longer exist after repo restructuring (commit 34d756e)

description:
**DEVELOPER EXPERIENCE**

Write failing tests for the lakehouse.do SDK - the public interface for startup founders.

## Target File
`sdks/lakehouse.do/test/sdk.test.ts`

## Tests to Write
1. `lakehouse('name')` creates client
2. `lh.query(sql)` executes SQL query
3. `lh.search(embedding)` performs vector search
4. `lh\`natural language query\`` tagged template
5. `lh.table('name').insert()` CRUD operations
6. `lh.schema` returns introspection

## API Design
```typescript
import { lakehouse } from 'lakehouse.do'

const lh = lakehouse('my-warehouse')

// SQL query
const results = await lh.query('SELECT * FROM customers LIMIT 10')

// Vector search
const similar = await lh.search(embedding, { limit: 5 })

// Natural language (tagged template)
const insights = await lh`top 10 customers by revenue this month`
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All tests written and failing
- [ ] Clean, intuitive API
- [ ] Tagged template support for NL

title: [GREEN] Implement users endpoint
description:
Implement GET /api/v2/users endpoint to pass RED phase tests.

## Zendesk API Behavior
- Returns max 100 users per page
- Response wrapper: `{ users: [...], next_page, previous_page, count }`
- Supports query params: role, per_page, page
- GET /api/v2/users/{id} returns `{ user: {...} }`

## Endpoints to Implement
```
GET /api/v2/users                    - List all users
GET /api/v2/users/{id}               - Show user
GET /api/v2/groups/{id}/users        - Users in group
GET /api/v2/organizations/{id}/users - Users in org
POST /api/v2/users                   - Create user
PUT /api/v2/users/{id}               - Update user
```

## Database Schema
```sql
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY,
  name TEXT NOT NULL,
  email TEXT UNIQUE,
  role TEXT DEFAULT 'end-user',
  active BOOLEAN DEFAULT true,
  organization_id INTEGER,
  phone TEXT,
  suspended BOOLEAN DEFAULT false,
  verified BOOLEAN DEFAULT false,
  user_fields TEXT,  -- JSON
  created_at TEXT NOT NULL,
  updated_at TEXT NOT NULL
);
```
acceptance_criteria:
- All RED phase tests pass
- GET /api/v2/users returns valid Zendesk-compatible response
- Single user endpoint works
- Role filtering works

title: [REFACTOR] Fix VectorInput type collision in cluster-manager.ts
description:
**CRITICAL BLOCKER**

The local `VectorInput` interface at line 111-116 shadows the imported type from `vector-distance.js` at line 21.

**Problem:**
```typescript
// Line 21: Imports VectorInput from vector-distance
import { ..., type VectorInput } from './vector-distance.js'

// Lines 111-117: Redefines VectorInput locally (COLLISION!)
export interface VectorInput {
  id: string
  vector: number[]
}
```

**Fix:**
Rename the local interface to `ClusterVectorInput` or `VectorBatchInput`

**Files:**
- packages/do-core/src/cluster-manager.ts:111-117
- packages/do-core/src/cluster-manager.ts:315 (usage)
close_reason: Fixed VectorInput type collision by renaming the local interface to VectorBatchInput. The imported VectorInput from vector-distance.js (type VectorInput = number[] | Float32Array) was colliding with a local interface definition with a different structure ({ id: string, vector: number[] }). Renamed the local interface to VectorBatchInput to accurately reflect its purpose for batch vector assignment. Also removed the unused VectorInput import. All 45 tests pass.

title: ARCH: No formal repository pattern - SQL queries embedded in DO class
description:
SQL queries are embedded directly in the DO class methods. While there are `repositories/` directories for some entities, the pattern is inconsistent:

Files found:
- `packages/do/src/repositories/event-repository.ts`
- `packages/do/src/repositories/action-repository.ts`

But most entity operations (Things, Relationships, Documents, Artifacts) have SQL directly in do.ts.

Issues:
1. SQL injection risk if not careful with parameter binding
2. No consistent data access layer
3. Hard to unit test business logic separately from storage
4. Raw SQL strings scattered throughout 3800+ line file

Recommendation:
1. Create repository classes for each entity type
2. Define repository interfaces for dependency injection
3. Use the existing repositories as pattern for new ones
4. DO delegates to repositories instead of direct SQL
close_reason: Completed: Repository pattern now implemented in packages/do-core/src/repository.ts with IRepository interface, BaseKVRepository, BaseSQLRepository, Query builder, and UnitOfWork pattern. Concrete implementations exist in things-repository.ts and events-repository.ts

title: [REFACTOR] Fix double any cast in parquet-serializer.ts
description:
**Important Issue**

Double `any` cast bypasses type safety in a core deserialization path.

**Problem:**
```typescript
// parquet-serializer.ts:911-912
(filtered as any)[col] = (thing as any)[col]
```

**Fix:**
```typescript
if (col in thing) {
  (filtered as Record<string, unknown>)[col] = thing[col as keyof Thing]
}
```

**File:** packages/do-core/src/parquet-serializer.ts:911-912
close_reason: Fixed the double any cast in parquet-serializer.ts by replacing `(filtered as any)[col] = (thing as any)[col]` with proper type-safe casting: `(filtered as Record<string, unknown>)[col] = thing[col as keyof Thing]`. The fix removes the eslint-disable comment and maintains full type safety while preserving the same runtime behavior.

title: JWKS cache uses module-level Map, leaks between DO instances
description:
In `/packages/do/src/auth/jwt-validation.ts` line 127:

```typescript
const jwksCache: Map<string, CachedJWKS> = new Map()
```

This module-level cache is shared across all DO instances within the same isolate. While this is memory-efficient for caching, it means:

1. Cache entries persist even after DO instances are evicted
2. No way to invalidate cache per-DO instance
3. In Cloudflare Workers, isolate reuse means stale data could persist

**Recommended fix**: Consider making the cache instance-level or adding a maximum cache size with LRU eviction.
close_reason:
Implemented instance-isolated JWKS cache with factory pattern. The previous module-level Map that leaked between DO instances has been replaced with:

1. JWKSCacheFactory - creates isolated caches per DO instance
2. Per-instance JWKSCache with TTL support and automatic expiration
3. Global LRU eviction when total cache size exceeds limit
4. Proper cleanup when DO instances are destroyed

All 17 JWKS cache tests pass, plus 32 existing RBAC tests.

1. GET /Encounter?patient=12345&_count=10&status=finished returns encounters for patient

6. GET /Encounter?_id=12345,67890 returns multiple encounters

12. GET /Encounter?patient=12345&status=planned returns planned encounters
13. GET /Encounter?patient=12345&status=in-progress returns active encounters
14. GET /Encounter?patient=12345&status=finished returns completed encounters
15. GET /Encounter?patient=12345&status=cancelled returns cancelled encounters

```json
{

  "type": "searchset",
  "total": 5,
  "entry": [
    {
      "fullUrl": "https://fhir.example.com/r4/Encounter/97939518",

        "id": "97939518",
        "status": "finished",
        "class": { "system": "...", "code": "IMP", "display": "inpatient" },
        "subject": { "reference": "Patient/12345" },
        "period": { "start": "2024-01-15T08:00:00Z", "end": "2024-01-17T14:00:00Z" }
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

title: packages/glyphs: GREEN - 入 (invoke/fn) function invocation implementation
close_reason:
Implemented the 入 (invoke/fn) function invocation glyph. All 78 tests pass. Key implementation details:

1. Created a Proxy-based approach that allows the result to be both:
   - A Promise (for direct await: `await 入`fn``)
   - A callable function (for chaining: `.then(入`fn`)`)

2. Uses lazy evaluation - the function is only invoked when:
   - The promise is awaited/then'd (for direct use)
   - The proxy is called as a function (in .then() chains)

3. Supports all required features:
   - Tagged template invocation with arguments
   - Function registration with .register()
   - Direct invocation with .invoke()
   - Pipeline composition with .pipe()
   - Middleware support with .use()
   - Retry and timeout handling
   - Proper error propagation through chains
   - instanceof Promise returns true

title: [REFACTOR] Iceberg module optimization
description:
Refactor Iceberg modules for performance and maintainability.

## Target Files
- `packages/do-core/src/iceberg-*.ts`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All tests still pass
- [ ] Unified Iceberg API
- [ ] Efficient metadata operations
- [ ] Document public API

## Complexity: M
close_reason:
Refactored Iceberg module with the following optimizations:

1. **Metadata Caching**: Added `MetadataCache` class with TTL support for catalog, table, and schema discovery. Configurable via `enableMetadataCache` and `metadataCacheTtl` options.

2. **SQL Injection Protection**: Added `escapeIdentifier()` and `escapeString()` utility functions to properly escape SQL identifiers and string literals.

3. **Typed Error Classes**: Added `IcebergCatalogError` and `IcebergTableError` classes that extend `IcebergConnectionError` with contextual information (catalog name, table name).

4. **Unified Iceberg API**: Added new `Iceberg` class providing a clean, unified API with `Iceberg.connect()`, `catalog()`, `tables()`, `schema()`, `query()`, and cache management methods.

5. **New Configuration Options**:
   - `enableMetadataCache`: Enable/disable caching
   - `metadataCacheTtl`: Cache TTL in milliseconds

6. **Cache Management Methods**:
   - `clearCache()`: Clear all cached metadata
   - `getCacheStats()`: Get cache statistics for monitoring

7. **API Options**:
   - `DiscoverTablesOptions.skipCache`: Force fresh data
   - `GetSchemaOptions.skipCache`: Force fresh schema

8. **Comprehensive JSDoc Documentation**: All public interfaces, classes, and functions documented with examples.

All changes are backward compatible with existing code.

title: REFACTOR: Add observability hooks and metrics
description:
## Refactoring Goal
Add comprehensive observability to the platform.

## Current State
Limited logging, no metrics or tracing.

## Target State
```typescript
// Metrics
export class Metrics {
  counter(name: string, value?: number, tags?: Tags): void
  gauge(name: string, value: number, tags?: Tags): void
  histogram(name: string, value: number, tags?: Tags): void
  timing(name: string, ms: number, tags?: Tags): void
}

// Tracing
export class Tracer {
  startSpan(name: string, options?: SpanOptions): Span
  activeSpan(): Span | null
}

interface Span {
  setTag(key: string, value: string): void
  log(data: object): void
  finish(): void
}

// Hooks
export interface ObservabilityHooks {
  onRequest(request: Request): void
  onResponse(request: Request, response: Response, duration: number): void
  onError(error: Error, request?: Request): void
  onStorageOperation(op: string, key: string, duration: number): void
}
```

## Requirements
- Metrics export (Prometheus format)
- Distributed tracing (OpenTelemetry)
- Structured logging
- Error tracking

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Metrics collected
- [ ] Traces generated
- [ ] Logs structured
- [ ] All tests pass
notes: NOT IMPLEMENTED: wrangler.toml missing observability.enabled=true. No structured logging, metrics/tracing hooks, or OpenTelemetry integration. Requires: 1) Add observability config to wrangler.toml, 2) Implement Metrics class, 3) Add OpenTelemetry tracing, 4) Create ObservabilityHooks interface.
close_reason: Implemented @dotdo/observability package with Metrics (counter, gauge, histogram, timing), Tracer (spans, events, attributes), ObservabilityHooks for request/response lifecycle, PrometheusExporter for /metrics endpoint, and WorkerIntegration for wrapping handlers. All 93 tests pass.

title: ARCH: Schema initialization called on every operation
description:
The `initSchema()` method is called at the start of nearly every operation (get, list, create, update, delete, search, etc.). While it has a `schemaInitialized` flag, this pattern has issues:

1. Adds overhead to every call (even if just a boolean check)
2. Not atomic - could have race conditions in concurrent scenarios  
3. Should use `blockConcurrencyWhile()` in constructor for proper initialization

Recommended fix:
```typescript
constructor(ctx: DurableObjectState, env: Env) {
  this.ctx = ctx
  this.env = env
  ctx.blockConcurrencyWhile(async () => {
    await this.initSchema()
  })
}
```

This ensures schema is initialized once, atomically, before any requests are processed.

Implement role-based access control to pass RED phase tests.

## Implementation
```typescript
type UserRole = 'end-user' | 'agent' | 'admin'

const ROLE_PERMISSIONS: Record<UserRole, string[]> = {
  'end-user': ['tickets:own', 'requests:create'],
  'agent': ['tickets:read', 'tickets:write', 'users:read', 'views:read'],
  'admin': ['*']  // Full access
}

function hasPermission(user: User, permission: string): boolean {
  const perms = ROLE_PERMISSIONS[user.role]
  return perms.includes('*') || perms.includes(permission)
}
```

## Middleware
- Extract user from auth token/session
- Check permissions before route handlers
- Return 403 Forbidden for unauthorized access

## Special Cases
- end-user can only GET /api/v2/requests (not /tickets)
- agent sees tickets filtered by group membership
- Suspended users (suspended: true) blocked from all access
acceptance_criteria:
- All role-based access tests pass
- end-user restrictions enforced
- agent group-based access works
- admin has full access
- Suspended users blocked

title: [GREEN] Implement ticket state machine
description:
Implement ticket status state machine to pass RED phase tests.

## Implementation
```typescript
const VALID_TRANSITIONS: Record<TicketStatus, TicketStatus[]> = {
  new: ['open', 'pending', 'hold', 'solved'],
  open: ['pending', 'hold', 'solved'],
  pending: ['open', 'hold', 'solved'],
  hold: ['open', 'pending', 'solved'],
  solved: ['open'],  // Reopen only
  closed: [],        // Terminal state
}

function canTransition(from: TicketStatus, to: TicketStatus): boolean {
  return VALID_TRANSITIONS[from].includes(to)
}
```

## Edge Cases
- Return 422 Unprocessable Entity for invalid transitions
- closed tickets return 409 Conflict on any update attempt
- Auto-close behavior (tickets solved for X days) - separate automation
acceptance_criteria:
- All status transition tests pass
- Invalid transitions return proper error codes
- State machine is reusable for triggers/automations

title: RED: Test SDK endpoint format consistency
description:
Write tests that verify all SDKs use consistent endpoint format.

Test file: `packages/sdk-lint/test/endpoints.test.ts` (or scripts/)

Currently inconsistent:
- `llm.do`: `createClient<LLMClient>('https://llm.do', options)` (full URL)
- `workflows.do`: `createClient<WorkflowsClient>('workflows', options)` (service name only)

Tests should:
1. Parse all SDK index.ts files
2. Extract createClient calls
3. Verify all use same format (recommend: full URL)
4. Report any inconsistencies
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test exists that checks all SDKs
- [ ] Test fails for inconsistent SDKs
notes:
## Script Created

`scripts/lint-sdk-endpoints.ts` - Lints all SDKs for endpoint format consistency.

## Findings

**13 SDKs using inconsistent (service name only) format:**
- events.do: 'events' -> 'https://events.do' (line 66)
- functions.do: 'functions' -> 'https://functions.do' (line 76)
- goals.do: 'goals' -> 'https://goals.do' (line 306)
- kpis.do: 'kpis' -> 'https://kpis.do' (line 398)
- nouns.do: 'nouns' -> 'https://nouns.do' (line 331)
- okrs.do: 'okrs' -> 'https://okrs.do' (line 371)
- plans.do: 'plans' -> 'https://plans.do' (line 332)
- projects.do: 'projects' -> 'https://projects.do' (line 522)
- resources.do: 'resources' -> 'https://resources.do' (line 445)
- services.do: 'services' -> 'https://services.do' (line 109)
- tasks.do: 'tasks' -> 'https://tasks.do' (line 405)
- verbs.do: 'verbs' -> 'https://verbs.do' (line 317)
- workflows.do: 'workflows' -> 'https://workflows.do' (line 286)

**40 SDKs using correct (full URL) format.**

**3 SDKs without createClient (intentional):**
- cli.do (CLI framework, no RPC)
- mcp.do (MCP protocol, local factory)
- mdxui (React component library)

## Usage

```bash
npx tsx scripts/lint-sdk-endpoints.ts          # Human-readable output
npx tsx scripts/lint-sdk-endpoints.ts --json   # Machine-readable JSON
npx tsx scripts/lint-sdk-endpoints.ts --help   # Show help
```

Exit code 0 = all consistent, exit code 1 = inconsistencies found.
close_reason: Script created and findings documented. Found 13 inconsistent SDKs that need updating (workers-vacd).

title: Event-Sourced Lakehouse Platform
description: Master epic for AI-native data platform on Cloudflare combining event sourcing with tiered lakehouse storage. Foundation for platform rewrites of Snowflake, Databricks, Teradata, Cloudera, Firebolt, and SAP HANA.
design:
## Architecture Overview

**Three-Tier Storage:**
- Hot: DO SQLite (events, projections, HNSW vectors)
- Warm: R2 Parquet (row groups with statistics)
- Cold: R2 Iceberg (snapshots, time-travel, schema evolution)

**Query Routing:**
- Point lookups → Hot tier (DO SQLite)
- Aggregations → Warm/Cold (R2 SQL)
- Vector search → Hot HNSW + Cold clustered scan

**Agent Integration:**
- Natural language to SQL translation
- Role-based access control
- Collaborative data science workflows
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] LakehouseEvent type extends DomainEvent with partition keys, schema version, embeddings
- [ ] TieredStorageMixin routes events through hot→warm→cold pipeline
- [ ] QueryRouter selects optimal tier(s) based on query analysis
- [ ] VectorSearchMixin supports MRL truncation for tiered search
- [ ] Agent permissions enforce row/column level security
- [ ] SDK provides unified query interface across all tiers

title: packages/glyphs - Visual DSL for TypeScript
description:
Create a visual programming DSL using CJK glyphs as valid TypeScript identifiers.

Core glyphs:
- 入 (fn) = function/invoke
- 人 (do) = worker/agent
- 巛 (on) = event/stream
- 彡 (db) = database
- 田 (c) = collection
- 目 (ls) = list
- 口 (T) = type/schema
- 回 ($) = instance
- 亘 (www) = site/page
- ılıl (m) = metrics
- 卌 (q) = queue

Each glyph exports both the visual symbol and ASCII alias.
design:
## Architecture

Tagged template literals for natural language invocation:
```typescript
const result = await 人`review this code`
```

Dual exports for accessibility:
```typescript
export { invoke as 入, invoke as fn }
```

Type-safe with full TypeScript inference.

## Layers
1. Foundation - types, exports, package setup
2. Type System - 口 (type), 回 (instance)
3. Data Layer - 田 (collection), 目 (list), 彡 (db)
4. Execution - 入 (invoke), 人 (worker)
5. Flow - 巛 (event), 卌 (queue)
6. Output - 亘 (site), ılıl (metrics)
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] All 11 glyphs implemented and exported
- [ ] ASCII aliases for each glyph
- [ ] Full TypeScript type inference
- [ ] Tagged template literal support
- [ ] Tree-shakable exports
- [ ] 100% test coverage
- [ ] Documentation with examples

title: Implement builder.domains - Free Domains for Builders
description:
Implement the builder.domains platform service providing free domains for AI agents and builders.

**Free Tier Domains:**
- *.hq.com.ai - AI Headquarters
- *.app.net.ai - AI Applications
- *.api.net.ai - AI APIs
- *.hq.sb - StartupBuilder Headquarters
- *.io.sb - StartupBuilder IO
- *.llc.st - LLC domains

**Paid Tier:**
- Premium base domains (custom TLDs)
- Premium individual domains
- High-volume domain allocation
- Custom DNS and routing

**API (env.DOMAINS):**
- claim(domain) - Claim a free domain
- route(domain, config) - Configure routing to workers
- list() - List claimed domains
- release(domain) - Release a domain

**Integration Points:**
- Cloudflare for DNS and routing
- Workers for Platforms for custom domains
- Dashboard for domain management UI
close_reason:
Implemented builder.domains - Free Domains for Builders. The implementation includes:

**Core Implementation (`workers/domains/src/domains.ts`)**:
- DomainsDO Durable Object with full domain lifecycle management
- Free TLDs: hq.com.ai, app.net.ai, api.net.ai, hq.sb, io.sb, llc.st
- Domain claiming with org ownership
- Domain routing to workers
- Domain listing and counting per organization
- Domain validation (subdomain format, TLD checking)
- Rate limiting and concurrency control via blockConcurrencyWhile
- HTTP fetch handler with REST API and RPC endpoints
- HATEOAS discovery endpoint

**API Methods**:
- claim(domain, orgId) - Claim a free domain
- release(domain, orgId) - Release a domain
- route(domain, config, orgId) - Configure routing to workers

```
DO SQLite (Hot) → R2 Parquet (Warm) → R2 Iceberg (Cold)
```

1. Event Sourcing Foundation
2. Tiered Storage Migration
3. Vector Search with MRL
4. Pipeline Integration
5. Query Routing
6. R2 SQL Analytics

## Success Metrics
- Sub-millisecond hot queries
- 93% storage cost reduction via tiering
- Vector search across hot+cold with <2% accuracy loss
- Complete event audit trail

title: GREEN: Prototype Pollution prevention implementation passes tests
description:
Harden sandbox against prototype pollution attacks.

## Solution
Add runtime pattern detection before creating Function:

```typescript
const dangerousPatterns = [
  /__proto__/,
  /constructor\\s*\\.\\s*constructor/,
  /Object\\s*\\.\\s*getPrototypeOf/,
  /Reflect\\s*\\./,
  /\\[\\s*['"]constructor['"]\\s*\\]/,
]

for (const pattern of dangerousPatterns) {
  if (pattern.test(code)) {
    throw new Error('Potentially dangerous code pattern detected')
  }
}
```

## Files
- `src/do.ts:748-870` - Sandbox implementation
close_reason: Closed

title: Documentation
description: Documentation for @dotdo/workers platform. Includes API docs, extension patterns, deployment guide, and example applications.

title: TASK: Create API documentation with TypeDoc
description:
## Task
Generate comprehensive API documentation using TypeDoc.

## Requirements
- Configure TypeDoc for the project
- Document all public APIs
- Include code examples
- Generate both HTML and Markdown output
- Host on docs.workers.do

## Implementation
```json
// typedoc.json
{
  "entryPoints": ["src/index.ts"],
  "out": "docs/api",
  "plugin": ["typedoc-plugin-markdown"],
  "readme": "README.md",
  "excludePrivate": true,
  "excludeInternal": true
}
```

## Documentation Structure
- Getting Started
- API Reference
  - DO Class
  - Mixins
  - Utilities
- Type Definitions

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] TypeDoc configured
- [ ] All public APIs documented
- [ ] Examples included
- [ ] Docs hosted
close_reason: TypeDoc API documentation setup complete. Created typedoc.json configuration, added npm scripts (docs, docs:html, docs:watch), and generated comprehensive Markdown documentation in docs/api/ covering all Durable Objects (Agent, Workflow, Human, etc.) and packages (do-core, auth, health, etc.)

title: TASK: Write extension patterns guide
description:
## Task
Write a comprehensive guide on extending the DO platform.

## Topics to Cover
1. **Creating Custom Mixins**
   - Mixin architecture
   - Implementing abstract methods
   - Composing multiple mixins

2. **Custom Event Handlers**
   - Event system overview
   - Creating event handlers
   - Event sourcing patterns

3. **Adding New Actions**
   - Action registration
   - Action middleware
   - Async action patterns

4. **Storage Extensions**
   - Custom repositories
   - Index strategies
   - Query optimization

5. **Transport Extensions**
   - Custom WebSocket handlers
   - RPC extensions
   - Custom protocols

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Mixin guide complete
- [ ] Event patterns documented
- [ ] Action patterns documented
- [ ] Storage patterns documented
- [ ] Code examples for each
close_reason: Created comprehensive extension patterns guide at docs/EXTENSION-PATTERNS.md covering all five required topics: (1) Creating Custom Mixins - mixin architecture, implementing abstract methods, composing multiple mixins; (2) Custom Event Handlers - pub/sub events, event sourcing, WebSocket broadcast integration; (3) Adding New Actions - action registration, middleware, async patterns, workflow orchestration; (4) Storage Extensions - custom repositories, index strategies, query optimization, Unit of Work pattern; (5) Transport Extensions - custom WebSocket handlers, JSON-RPC extensions, custom protocols, RPC service bindings. All sections include detailed code examples.

title: TASK: Create deployment guide
description:
## Task
Write a step-by-step deployment guide for workers.do.

## Topics to Cover
1. **Prerequisites**
   - Account setup
   - CLI installation
   - Configuration

2. **First Deployment**

   - Deploying to workers.do

3. **Custom Domains**
   - Adding a custom domain
   - DNS configuration
   - SSL certificates

4. **Environment Configuration**
   - Environment variables
   - Secrets management
   - Multiple environments

5. **CI/CD Integration**
   - GitHub Actions
   - GitLab CI
   - Other platforms

6. **Monitoring & Debugging**
   - Logs
   - Metrics
   - Error tracking

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Prerequisites documented
- [ ] Step-by-step guide complete
- [ ] Custom domains covered
- [ ] CI/CD examples provided
- [ ] Troubleshooting section
close_reason: Completed comprehensive deployment guide covering all required topics: prerequisites, first deployment, custom domains, environment configuration, CI/CD integration, monitoring/debugging, advanced deployment strategies, and troubleshooting.

title: RED: Test package.json validity for npm publish
description:
Write tests that verify all SDK package.json files are valid for npm publish.

Issues to detect:
1. `workspace:*` in peerDependencies (npm doesn't understand this)
2. Missing `types` field
3. Main pointing to .ts files (consumers need .js)
4. Missing `files` field
5. Invalid semver in dependencies

Test file: `scripts/test-package-validity.ts`

Run `npm pack --dry-run` on each SDK and verify no errors.
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test checks all package.json files
- [ ] Test fails for invalid configurations
notes:
## Script Created
Created `scripts/lint-package-json.ts` that validates SDK package.json files for npm publish.

Added `lint:packages` script to root package.json.

## Findings (Run: 2026-01-07)

```
Packages checked: 59
Packages with errors: 58
Packages with warnings: 0
Total errors: 228
Total warnings: 0

Specific issues:
  workspace:* in dependencies: 227
  workspace:* in peerDependencies: 1
```

### Only 1 package is clean
- `sdks/mdxui/package.json` - No issues

### Issue Breakdown
Most SDKs have 4 workspace dependencies that need to be fixed:
- `cli.do: workspace:*`
- `mcp.do: workspace:*`
- `org.ai: workspace:*`
- `rpc.do: workspace:*`

### Special cases
- `rpc.do` has `org.ai: workspace:*` in peerDependencies (should be `^0.1.0` or similar)
- `org.ai` has `rpc.do: workspace:*` in dependencies
- `workers.do` has 9 workspace dependencies (most complex)
- `workflow.as` has `ai-workflows: workspace:*`

### Next Steps
See workers-4kv6 (GREEN) for fix plan
close_reason: Completed - Created lint-package-json.ts script that detects 228 npm publish issues across 58 packages. Script exits with error code 1 when issues found. Added lint:packages script to root package.json.

title: GREEN: Add Hono context type augmentation for middleware
description:
The middleware package in packages/middleware/src uses Hono Context without proper type augmentation, which means `c.set()` and `c.get()` calls are not type-safe.

Current code (packages/middleware/src/auth/index.ts):
```typescript
c.set('auth', authContext)  // No type checking on key/value
return c.get('auth') ?? null  // Returns unknown
```

Rate limit middleware (packages/middleware/src/rate-limit/index.ts):
```typescript
const auth = c.get('auth')  // Returns unknown
return auth?.userId || defaultKeyGenerator(c)  // Type unsafe
```

Recommended solution - create Hono type augmentation:

```typescript
// packages/middleware/src/types.ts
import type { Context } from 'hono'

// Declare module augmentation for Hono context variables
declare module 'hono' {
  interface ContextVariableMap {
    auth: AuthContext | null
    rateLimitResult?: RateLimitResult
  }
}

// Export types
export interface AuthContext {
  userId?: string
  organizationId?: string
  permissions?: string[]
  token?: string
  metadata?: Record<string, unknown>
}
```

Benefits:
- Type-safe `c.get('auth')` returns `AuthContext | null` instead of `unknown`
- Type-safe `c.set('auth', value)` validates the value type
- Better IDE autocomplete for context variables

title: TypeScript transpiler in CodeExecutor is too simplistic
description:
In `/packages/do/src/executor/index.ts` lines 100-143, the `transpileTypeScript()` function uses regex-based transpilation:

```typescript
// Remove type annotations from variable declarations
code = code.replace(/(\b(?:const|let|var)\s+\w+)\s*:\s*[^=]+=/g, '$1 =')

// Remove type annotations from function parameters
code = code.replace(/(\w+)\s*:\s*(?:number|string|boolean|...)/g, '$1')
```

This approach has several issues:
1. Regex cannot parse TypeScript properly - it will fail on complex types
2. No support for generics with complex constraints
3. No support for type guards, type assertions (`as`), or non-null assertions (`!`)
4. No support for decorators
5. No support for namespaces or modules
6. Enums are converted incorrectly for auto-incrementing numeric enums

**Recommended fix**: Use a proper TypeScript compiler (e.g., `typescript` package or `esbuild`) for transpilation.
close_reason: Duplicate of completed workers-green-ts: Robust TypeScript transpiler using TypeScript compiler API (ts.transpileModule) was implemented, handling all the issues mentioned in this ticket

title: [REFACTOR] Fix unsafe non-null assertion in cluster-manager.ts
description:
**Important Issue**

At line 298, `nearestClusterId!` assumes value is set, but on first iteration with equal distances it could be null.

**Problem:**
```typescript
if (distance < nearestDistance || 
    (distance === nearestDistance && clusterId < nearestClusterId!)) {
```

**Fix:**
```typescript
if (distance < nearestDistance || 
    (distance === nearestDistance && nearestClusterId !== null && clusterId < nearestClusterId)) {
```

**File:** packages/do-core/src/cluster-manager.ts:298
close_reason: Fixed unsafe non-null assertion at line 298 by adding explicit null check before string comparison

title: [GREEN] Implement query parser (^, ^OR, operators)
description:
Implement ServiceNow encoded query parser to pass the failing tests.

## Implementation Requirements
1. Parse encoded query string into AST
2. Support logical operators:
   - `^` for AND
   - `^OR` for OR  
   - `^NQ` for New Query (OR group)
3. Support comparison operators:
   - Equality: `=`, `!=`
   - String: `STARTSWITH`, `ENDSWITH`, `CONTAINS`, `LIKE`, `NOTLIKE`
   - List: `IN`, `NOTIN`
   - Null: `ISEMPTY`, `ISNOTEMPTY`
   - Numeric: `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=`, `BETWEEN`
4. Convert to SQL WHERE clause for D1/SQLite

## Example Transformations
```
active=true^priority=1
  -> WHERE active = 'true' AND priority = '1'

priority=1^ORpriority=2
  -> WHERE priority = '1' OR priority = '2'

numberSTARTSWITHINC001
  -> WHERE number LIKE 'INC001%'

priorityIN1,2,3
  -> WHERE priority IN ('1', '2', '3')
```

title: [RED] Hot index LRU eviction tests
description:
**MEMORY CONSTRAINT**

DO memory is limited (128MB). The hot index Map can grow unbounded. Write tests for LRU eviction.

## Target File
`packages/do-core/test/hot-index-lru.test.ts`

## Tests to Write
1. Index has configurable max size
2. Evicts least recently used entries when full
3. Access updates recency
4. Eviction triggers warm migration
5. Configurable eviction batch size
6. Memory estimation per entry
7. Preserves hot path performance

- [ ] Clear LRU semantics
- [ ] Integration with TierIndex

title: Migrate wrangler.toml to wrangler.jsonc format
description:
The project currently uses wrangler.toml but Cloudflare best practices recommend wrangler.jsonc (JSONC format) for configuration.

**Current state:**
- Using wrangler.toml with TOML syntax
- compatibility_date = "2024-09-25" (should be updated to 2025+)

**Required changes:**
1. Convert wrangler.toml → wrangler.jsonc
2. Update compatibility_date to recent (e.g., "2025-03-07")
3. Add observability config: `"observability": { "enabled": true, "head_sampling_rate": 1 }`
4. Ensure all bindings use JSONC syntax

**Example structure:**
```jsonc
{
  "name": "workers-test",
  "main": "packages/do/src/index.ts",
  "compatibility_date": "2025-03-07",
  "compatibility_flags": ["nodejs_compat"],
  "observability": { "enabled": true, "head_sampling_rate": 1 },
  "durable_objects": {
    "bindings": [{ "name": "DO_NAMESPACE", "class_name": "DO" }]
  },
  "migrations": [{ "tag": "v1", "new_sqlite_classes": ["DO"] }]
}
```
close_reason: COMPLETED: wrangler.jsonc already exists with proper format - compatibility_date='2025-03-07', observability config enabled, JSONC syntax used for all bindings. Task was marked in_progress but work was already complete.

title: Rewrite firebase.do README with business narrative
description:
firebase.do README is technically complete but missing the business narrative entirely.

## Current State
- Completeness: 4/5
- StoryBrand: 2/5 (weak problem statement, no cost savings story)
- API Elegance: 4/5

## Required Additions
1. **Problem section** - Firebase costs, lock-in, limitations
2. **Pricing comparison** - Firebase Blaze vs firebase.do cost analysis
3. **Migration story** - How to migrate from Firebase Cloud
4. **agents.do integration** - AI-native story

## Suggested Content
```markdown
## The Problem
Firebase is powerful, but the costs add up:
| Firebase Pricing | Cost |
| Firestore reads | $0.036/100k |
| Cloud Functions | $0.40/million |

A moderately active app: **$500-5,000/month**

### firebase.do Pricing
- DO requests: $0.15/million
- SQLite: $0.20/GB/month
**90-95% cost reduction** typical.
```

Reference hubspot.do and salesforce.do as templates.

title: EPIC: Supabase on Cloudflare Durable Objects
description:
Greenfield implementation of Supabase on Cloudflare Durable Objects with SQLite storage.

## Architecture
- SupabaseDO extends DO from @dotdo/do
- Single /rpc endpoint + streaming/WebSocket endpoints
- Tiered storage: SQLite hot, R2 warm

## Components
1. Core DO Layer - SupabaseDO base class
2. PostgREST API - REST API for database operations
3. Realtime - WebSocket subscriptions for changes
4. Auth - User authentication and JWT tokens
5. Storage - File storage bucket operations
6. Edge Functions - Deno-compatible function execution

## SQLite Limitations (vs Postgres)
- No LISTEN/NOTIFY - Use DO alarms and WebSocket broadcast
- No triggers - Use DO state machine patterns
- No stored procedures - Implement in TypeScript
- FTS5 for full-text search instead of tsvector

- Two-phase search: fast approximate → exact rerank
- Cluster-partitioned cold vectors

## Target: <2% accuracy loss with 93% storage savings

Implement comprehensive API compatibility with Greenhouse Harvest API for the greenhouse.do platform. This epic covers all major endpoint categories including Candidates, Applications, Jobs, Interviews, Scorecards, Offers, Job Board API, and Webhooks.

## Goal
Achieve API parity with Greenhouse Harvest API to enable:
- Drop-in replacement for existing Greenhouse integrations
- Migration path from Greenhouse to greenhouse.do
- Familiar API surface for developers

## Scope
- Candidates (CRUD, tags, attachments, activity feed)
- Applications (stages, advance/reject, transfer)
- Jobs (CRUD, hiring team, stages, openings)
- Interviews (scheduling, scorecards)
- Offers (create, update, status tracking)
- Job Board API (public job listings, applications)
- Webhooks (event notifications)
- Organization Structure (departments, offices, users)

## References
- Harvest API: https://developers.greenhouse.io/harvest.html
- Job Board API: https://developers.greenhouse.io/job-board.html
- Webhooks: https://developers.greenhouse.io/webhooks.html

title: CodeExecutor uses Node.js vm module - incompatible with Workers runtime
description:
In `/packages/do/src/executor/index.ts` line 14:

```typescript
import vm from 'vm'
```

The `CodeExecutor` class uses Node.js's `vm` module for sandboxed code execution. This module is not available in the Cloudflare Workers runtime and will cause import errors.

The code also references `process.memoryUsage()` at lines 172-174, 412-413, and 426-427 which is also unavailable in Workers.

**Recommended fix**: 
1. Create a Worker-compatible executor using Cloudflare's isolate mechanisms
2. Use feature detection to switch between Node.js and Workers implementations
3. Consider using the `workerd` runtime's built-in isolation capabilities
close_reason: Duplicate of workers-sec.4 - CodeExecutor runtime issue tracked separately

title: [RED] Test POST /api/v2/tickets validates like Zendesk
description:
Write failing tests for ticket creation validation matching Zendesk API.

## Zendesk Create Ticket Request
```typescript
// POST /api/v2/tickets
{
  ticket: {
    subject: string          // Required
    comment: {               // Required - becomes description
      body: string
      public?: boolean       // default true
    }
    requester_id?: number    // OR requester object
    requester?: {
      name: string           // Required if using object
      email: string          // Required if using object
      locale_id?: number
    }
    priority?: 'urgent' | 'high' | 'normal' | 'low'
    type?: 'problem' | 'incident' | 'question' | 'task'
    tags?: string[]
    custom_fields?: Array<{ id: number, value: any }>
    assignee_id?: number
    group_id?: number
  }
}
```

## Test Cases
1. Valid ticket creation returns 201 with ticket object
2. Missing subject returns 422 with error details
3. Missing comment returns 422
4. requester can be ID or inline object
5. Idempotency key prevents duplicate creation
6. Tags inherit from parent for follow-up tickets
7. Returns Location header with ticket URL
acceptance_criteria:
- Tests cover all required field validation
- Tests verify idempotency key behavior (2 hour expiry)
- Tests verify requester resolution (ID vs inline)
- Tests verify response format matches Zendesk

title: ARCH: Missing interface abstraction between DO and transport layers
description:
The DO class directly handles HTTP routing (Hono), WebSocket messages, and RPC invocation. There is no clean interface abstraction separating the business logic from transport concerns.

Current issues:
1. `handleRequest()` directly parses headers and routes requests
2. `webSocketMessage()` directly handles JSON-RPC protocol
3. Auth extraction is duplicated between HTTP and WebSocket handlers
4. Transport-specific code mixed with domain logic

Recommended architecture:
1. Define `TransportHandler` interface with `handle(request)` method
2. Create `HttpTransport`, `WebSocketTransport`, `RpcTransport` implementations
3. DO provides `invoke()` as the single entry point for all transports
4. Transports handle protocol translation and auth extraction

title: REFACTOR: Review and consolidate duplicate type definitions
description:
There are duplicate or overlapping type definitions that should be consolidated for maintainability.

Identified duplications:

1. **AuthContext** - defined in multiple places:
   - packages/do/src/types.ts:610-616
   - packages/middleware/src/auth/index.ts:12-18
   Both have the same shape but are separate definitions.

2. **RateLimitConfig/RateLimiter types** - overlapping definitions:
   - packages/do/src/types.ts:878-962 (RateLimitConfigType, RateLimitResultType, etc.)
   - packages/do/src/middleware/rate-limiter.ts (RateLimitConfig, RateLimitResult)
   The types.ts versions have "Type" suffix while middleware uses cleaner names.

3. **Entity types with branded vs unbranded versions**:
   - packages/do/src/types.ts:43-52 (EntityId as interface)
   - packages/do/src/types.ts:766 (EntityId as branded string)
   Same name used for different concepts.

Recommendations:
1. Create a shared types package or consolidate in packages/do/src/types.ts
2. Export types from packages/do and import in packages/middleware
3. Rename the branded EntityId to BrandedEntityId or EntityIdString to avoid confusion
4. Remove the "Type" suffix from rate limit types and use consistent naming
5. Add barrel exports for common types

title: process.env access in json-rpc.ts will fail in Workers environment
description:
In `/packages/do/src/rpc/json-rpc.ts` line 473:

```typescript
stack: process.env.NODE_ENV !== 'production' ? error.stack : undefined,
```

Cloudflare Workers don't have a `process` global. This will throw a ReferenceError when running in the Workers environment.

**Recommended fix**: Use a Worker-compatible environment detection method or remove the stack trace entirely for security.
notes:
Original path `/packages/do/src/rpc/json-rpc.ts` not found. Actual location of process.env.NODE_ENV issues found:
1. `/rewrites/mongo/src/mcp/adapters/errors.ts` line 158 - exact pattern from issue description
2. `/packages/esm/src/api/worker.ts` line 1304 - similar issue

The `/packages/do-core/src/json-rpc.ts` file has already been properly fixed to not use process.env.
close_reason:
Fixed process.env.NODE_ENV access in Workers-runtime code:

1. `/rewrites/mongo/src/mcp/adapters/errors.ts` (line 158): Removed conditional stack trace inclusion since process.env is unavailable in Workers. Stack traces are now intentionally omitted for security.

2. `/packages/esm/src/api/worker.ts` (line 1304): Removed conditional error details inclusion. Error details are now omitted from responses for security.

3. `/rewrites/mongo/src/mcp/adapters/anthropic-adapter.ts` (line 164): Changed verboseErrors default from process.env check to false. Callers should pass verboseErrors: true explicitly in config for development.

Note: The original path `/packages/do/src/rpc/json-rpc.ts` doesn't exist. The `/packages/do-core/src/json-rpc.ts` was already properly implemented to use Workers env bindings instead of process.env.

title: DO class is 2000+ lines - needs decomposition
description:
The main DO class in `/packages/do/src/do.ts` is over 2000 lines with 50+ methods covering:
- CRUD operations
- Thing operations
- Event operations
- Relationship operations
- Action operations
- Workflow operations
- CDC operations
- Auth operations
- Rate limiting
- Custom domains
- WebSocket handling
- Router creation

This violates single responsibility principle and makes the code hard to maintain and test.

**Recommended fix**: Decompose into smaller, focused modules:
- `DOStorage` - CRUD and SQL operations
- `DOThings` - Thing and relationship operations
- `DOEvents` - Event tracking and queries
- `DOActions` - Action lifecycle management
- `DOWorkflow` - Workflow handlers and schedules
- `DOAuth` - Authentication and authorization
- Keep `DO` as a thin facade that composes these modules

title: GREEN: SimpleCodeExecutor sandbox escape implementation passes tests
description:
In `/packages/do/src/sandbox/executor.ts` line 473:

```typescript
const fn = new Function(...contextKeys, 'console', wrappedCode)
```

The `SimpleCodeExecutor` blocks `new Function()` in the DANGEROUS_PATTERNS array but then uses it internally to execute code. This creates an inconsistency and potential confusion.

More importantly, the security documentation states:
> For production use with untrusted code, consider using V8 isolates via WorkerCodeExecutor (Cloudflare Workers) or MiniflareCodeExecutor (testing).

However, this warning is only in comments, not enforced programmatically.

**Recommended fix**: Add runtime detection of untrusted code scenarios and throw a clear error directing users to use V8 isolates.
close_reason:
GREEN phase completed. Implemented comprehensive sandbox escape prevention in SimpleCodeExecutor:

## Summary of Changes
- Removed broken security preamble that was causing errors by trying to modify frozen objects
- Added RESERVED_PARAM_NAMES set to filter out keywords that can't be used as function parameters in strict mode
- Enhanced globalThis proxy to block eval, exports, and global access
- Added dangerous pattern detection for:
  - `.__proto__` property access and assignment
  - `.prototype` modification patterns
  - `.constructor()` escape patterns (direct calls with string arguments)
  - `Object.setPrototypeOf` and `Reflect.setPrototypeOf` attacks on built-ins
- Added stack trace sanitization for return values (not just errors)

## Test Results
- **77 out of 80** sandbox security tests now pass (was 55/80 before)
- Fixed 22 previously failing tests
- 3 remaining edge cases tracked in workers-zbde for AST-based detection:
  1. Generator function constructor escape via variable assignment
  2. Proxy trap escapes (test expectation issue, not real vulnerability)
  3. Large array allocation (V8 engine behavior)

## Files Modified
- `/Users/nathanclevenger/projects/workers/packages/eval/src/index.ts`

## Related Issues
- Created workers-zbde to track remaining edge cases
- workers-z0ya (REFACTOR) will address AST-based validation for complete coverage

title: Implement RelationshipMixin for cascade operators
description:
Create a mixin that adds relationship cascade support to DOCore:

```typescript
interface RelationshipDefinition {
  type: '->' | '~>' | '<~' | '<-'
  targetDOBinding: string
  targetIdResolver: (entity: unknown) => string
  cascadeFields?: string[]
  onDelete?: 'cascade' | 'nullify' | 'restrict'
  onUpdate?: 'cascade' | 'ignore'
}

class RelationshipMixin<T extends DOCore> {
  defineRelation(name: string, def: RelationshipDefinition): void
  triggerCascade(operation: 'create' | 'update' | 'delete', entity: unknown): Promise<void>
}
```

Hard cascades (-> <-) execute synchronously, soft cascades (~> <~) queue for eventual processing.
close_reason: Implemented RelationshipMixin with full cascade operator support including hard (-> <-) and soft (~> <~) cascades, onDelete/onUpdate behaviors, event emission, and comprehensive test coverage (50 tests)

title: InMemoryRateLimiter never cleans up expired entries
description:
In `/packages/do/src/middleware/rate-limiter.ts`, the `InMemoryRateLimiter` class stores rate limit entries in a Map but never removes them after they expire:

```typescript
private limits: Map<string, RateLimitEntry> = new Map()
```

The `check()` method creates new entries when windows expire, but old entries with different keys accumulate indefinitely. This causes memory growth proportional to the number of unique clients over the lifetime of the DO instance.

**Recommended fix**: Add periodic cleanup of expired entries or use a bounded data structure with eviction.
close_reason: Implemented InMemoryRateLimitStorage and InMemoryRateLimiter classes with proper cleanup of expired entries. The fix uses setTimeout-based periodic cleanup that removes expired entries automatically. Added dispose() method to stop cleanup when the storage is no longer needed. All 15 tests pass.

title: ARCH: Tiered storage (LRUCache, ObjectIndex) not integrated with DO class
description:
The storage.ts file defines sophisticated tiered storage components:

- `LRUCache` - In-memory cache with TTL, eviction, byte limits
- `ObjectIndex` - Track object locations across tiers (hot, r2, parquet)
- `StorageTier` types, `CacheStats`, `TierStats`

However, these are NOT used in the DO class. The DO class directly accesses `ctx.storage.sql` for all operations without caching or tiering.

This is a missed optimization:
1. No caching layer for frequently accessed documents
2. R2 tiering mentioned in ARCHITECTURE.md but not implemented
3. CDC pipeline partially implemented but not connected to tiered storage

Recommendation:
1. Integrate LRUCache for hot objects
2. Implement object promotion/demotion between tiers
3. Use ObjectIndex to track multi-tier locations
4. Add cache invalidation on writes
close_reason: Duplicate of TDD issues workers-rwpd, workers-dnjl, workers-n9o2 which track this work in RED/GREEN/REFACTOR phases

title: RED: Test database.do interface validity
description:
Write tests that expose the DatabaseClient index signature conflict.

Test file: `sdks/database.do/test/interface.test.ts`

The current interface at line 187 has a conflict:
```typescript
export interface DatabaseClient {
  do: TaggedTemplate<Promise<unknown[]>>
  [entityType: string]: EntityOperations<unknown>  // Conflicts!
  track<T>(...): Promise<...>
  events: EventOperations
}
```

The index signature says ALL string keys return `EntityOperations<unknown>`, but `do`, `track`, `events` return different types.

Tests should:
1. Try to compile an interface with this pattern
2. Verify TypeScript rejects it (or document if it somehow works)
3. Define expected entity access pattern
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Test demonstrates the type conflict
- [ ] Documents expected behavior
notes:
## Findings

### TypeScript Compiler Output
Running `pnpm tsc --noEmit sdks/database.do/index.ts` produces **14 TS2411 errors**:

1. `do` - TaggedTemplate is not assignable to EntityOperations
2. `track` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
3. `events` - Function returning Promise<Array> is not assignable
4. `send` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
5. `action` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
6. `actions` - Function returning Promise<Array> is not assignable
7. `completeAction` - Function returning Promise<void> is not assignable
8. `failAction` - Function returning Promise<void> is not assignable
9. `storeArtifact` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
10. `getArtifact` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
11. `deleteArtifact` - Function returning Promise<boolean> is not assignable
12. `schema` - Function returning Promise is not assignable
13. `types` - Function returning Promise<string[]> is not assignable
14. `describe` - Function returning Promise is not assignable

### Root Cause
The interface declares an index signature `[entityType: string]: EntityOperations<unknown>` which requires ALL string keys to return EntityOperations. But 14 explicit properties return different types.

### Test File Created
`sdks/database.do/test/interface.test.ts` with 5 tests:
- Demonstrates the conflicting pattern
- Lists all 14 conflicting properties
- Documents expected entity access patterns
- Documents possible solutions
- Verifies TypeScript behavior

### Tests Pass
All 5 tests pass, documenting the issue.
close_reason: Test file created and passing. Documented 14 TS2411 type errors in DatabaseClient interface. The index signature conflict is confirmed and thoroughly documented.

title: GREEN: Implement rpc.do client with WS→HTTP fallback
description:
Implement the rpc.do client to make all RED tests pass:

1. **ClientOptions Interface**
```typescript
interface ClientOptions {
  baseURL?: string  // defaults to 'https://rpc.do'
  apiKey?: string
  transport?: 'ws' | 'http' | 'auto'  // defaults to 'auto'
  wsReconnectAttempts?: number
  wsReconnectDelay?: number
}
```

2. **createClient Function**
```typescript
export function createClient<T>(service: string, options?: ClientOptions): T {
  const baseURL = options?.baseURL ?? 'https://rpc.do'
  // Implementation with WS→HTTP fallback
}
```

3. **Transport Layer**
- Try WebSocket first (`wss://rpc.do/ws/{service}`)
- On WS failure, fall back to HTTP POST (`https://rpc.do/rpc/{service}`)
- Use capnweb for serialization

4. **Update All SDKs**
- Each SDK's PascalCase factory should pass through options to createClient
- Default export should use `https://rpc.do` as baseURL

Files to modify:
- `sdks/rpc.do/index.ts` - Core client implementation
- `sdks/*/index.ts` - All SDK factory functions
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] All RED tests pass
- [ ] BaseURL defaults to https://rpc.do
- [ ] WS transport attempts connection first
- [ ] HTTP fallback works when WS fails
- [ ] All SDK factories accept baseURL option
- [ ] No regressions in existing functionality
notes:
RED phase complete. 18 failing tests to make pass:
1. WebSocket transport (transport: 'ws')
2. Auto transport with WS→HTTP fallback
3. Connection state methods (isConnected, disconnect, close)
4. Transport events (on('transportChange'))
5. Transport state (getTransport())
6. WS reconnection after backoff
7. Fix 4xx retry bug (currently retries 4xx, should not)
close_reason: GREEN phase complete: All 43 tests pass including WebSocket transport, HTTP fallback, connection state, transport events

title: Migrate TDD issues from workers/.beads to individual rewrite beads
description:
During session planning, ~100+ TDD issues (RED→GREEN→REFACTOR chains) were created for rewrites (supabase, gitx, mongo, kafka, firebase) but the MCP tools placed them all in workers/.beads instead of individual rewrite beads.

**Root Cause**: MCP tools resolve workspace context to workers/.beads regardless of workspace_root parameter.

**Required Migration**:
1. Extract TDD issues by prefix pattern from workers/.beads
2. Move to appropriate rewrite beads:
   - supabase-* → rewrites/supabase/.beads
   - gitx-* → rewrites/gitx/.beads  
   - mongo-* → rewrites/mongo/.beads
   - kafka-* → rewrites/kafka/.beads
   - firebase-* → rewrites/firebase/.beads

3. Delete migrated issues from workers/.beads
4. Verify dependency chains intact after migration

**Workaround**: Use `bd` CLI from within each rewrite directory (respects local .beads context) for future issue creation.
close_reason: Issues are already in correct rewrite beads - migration not needed. MCP was showing workers context by default.

title: [GREEN] Implement display value resolution
description:
Implement sysparm_display_value parameter handling to pass the failing tests.

## Implementation Requirements
1. Parse sysparm_display_value parameter (false/true/all)
2. Track which fields are reference fields via schema metadata
3. Resolve display values from referenced tables
4. Format response based on display_value mode:
   - `false`: Return raw sys_id value
   - `true`: Return resolved display value string
   - `all`: Return object with value, display_value, and link

## Schema Metadata Needed
```typescript
interface FieldMetadata {
  name: string
  type: 'string' | 'integer' | 'reference' | 'datetime' | ...
  reference_table?: string  // For reference fields
  display_field?: string    // Which field to use for display value
}
```

## Display Value Resolution Logic
```typescript
async function resolveDisplayValue(
  tableName: string,
  fieldName: string,
  sysId: string
): Promise<string> {
  const refTable = getFieldMetadata(tableName, fieldName).reference_table
  const displayField = getDisplayField(refTable) // name, number, etc.
  return db.query(`SELECT ${displayField} FROM ${refTable} WHERE sys_id = ?`, [sysId])
}
```

- Analytics pipeline for usage tracking
- Dashboard for LLM usage visualization

title: sdk/iceberg - Iceberg SDK with Worker
description: Native Iceberg SDK for Cloudflare with integrated Worker. Catalog API, table management, snapshot operations, R2 SQL integration.
design:
## SDK Interface
```typescript
import { iceberg } from 'iceberg.do'

const catalog = iceberg.catalog('lakehouse')
const table = await catalog.createTable('events', schema)
await table.append(records)
await table.snapshot.commit()

const results = await table.scan()
  .filter(col('timestamp').gt('2024-01-01'))
  .select(['id', 'type', 'payload'])
  .execute()
```

## Components
- Iceberg Catalog API (namespaces, tables)
- Schema evolution support
- Partition spec management
- Snapshot operations (commit, rollback)
- R2 SQL query integration

title: [REFACTOR] Extract duplicate cosineSimilarity to shared utility
description:
**DRY Violation**

Two separate `computeCosineSimilarity` implementations exist with different behavior:

title: Memory leak: Branded type Sets grow unbounded
description:
In `/packages/do/src/types.ts` lines 769-771, branded type tracking uses global Sets that never get cleaned up:

```typescript
const brandedEntityUrls = new Set<string>()
const brandedCollectionIds = new Set<string>()
const brandedEntityIds = new Set<string>()
```

Every call to `createEntityUrl()`, `createCollectionId()`, or `createEntityId()` adds to these Sets permanently. In a long-running Durable Object, this will cause unbounded memory growth.

**Recommended fix**: 
1. Use WeakSet or WeakRef if possible
2. Add a cleanup mechanism with TTL
3. Consider whether runtime tracking is actually needed (TypeScript's branded types work at compile time)
close_reason:
Implemented BoundedSet and BoundedMap classes that provide memory-safe tracking of branded types. The implementation includes:
- Configurable maxSize limits (default 10000)
- FIFO and LRU eviction policies
- TTL-based expiration with optional refresh on access
- Automatic periodic cleanup via configurable interval
- Statistics tracking (evictions, hits, misses, hit rate)
- Full Set/Map interface compatibility
- Resource cleanup via destroy() method

All 39 tests pass including size limits, FIFO/LRU eviction, TTL handling, Set/Map interface methods, and memory bounds under load.

[RED] Patient resource search endpoint tests
description:
Write failing tests for the FHIR R4 Patient search endpoint.

## Test Cases - Search by ID
1. GET /Patient?_id=12345 returns Bundle with matching patient
2. GET /Patient?_id=12345,67890 returns Bundle with multiple patients
3. GET /Patient?_id=nonexistent returns empty Bundle (total: 0)

## Test Cases - Search by Identifier
4. GET /Patient?identifier=urn:oid:1.1.1.1|12345 returns matching patient
5. GET /Patient?identifier=SSN|123-45-6789 finds patient (but SSN not in response)

## Test Cases - Search by Name
6. GET /Patient?name=Smith returns patients with matching given or family name
7. GET /Patient?name:exact=Smith returns exact matches only
8. GET /Patient?family=Smith&given=John returns patients matching both
9. GET /Patient?family:exact=Smith searches current names only (by period)

## Test Cases - Search by Demographics
10. GET /Patient?birthdate=1990-01-15 returns patients born on date
11. GET /Patient?birthdate=ge1990-01-01&birthdate=le1990-12-31 returns date range
12. GET /Patient?gender=male returns male patients
13. GET /Patient?address-postalcode=12345 returns patients at zip code
14. GET /Patient?phone=5551234567 returns patient with phone
15. GET /Patient?email=test@example.com returns patient with email

## Test Cases - Pagination
16. GET /Patient?name=Smith&_count=10 limits results per page
17. Response includes Link header with next URL when more results
18. Response returns 422 if >1000 patients match

## Response Shape
```json
{
  "resourceType": "Bundle",
  "type": "searchset",
  "total": 1,
  "link": [
    { "relation": "self", "url": "..." },
    { "relation": "next", "url": "..." }
  ],
  "entry": [
    {
      "fullUrl": "https://fhir.example.com/r4/Patient/12345",
      "resource": {
        "resourceType": "Patient",
        "id": "12345",
        "identifier": [...],
        "name": [...],
        "gender": "male",
        "birthDate": "1990-01-15"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

title: [RED] Test Azure AD OAuth flow
description:
Write failing tests for Azure AD OAuth 2.0 authentication flow matching Dynamics 365/Dataverse.

## Research Context
- Dataverse uses Azure AD for authentication
- OAuth 2.0 authorization code flow
- Client credentials flow for service-to-service
- Bearer token authentication

## Test Cases
### OAuth 2.0 Authorization Code Flow
1. Redirect to Azure AD login
2. Handle authorization callback with code
3. Exchange code for tokens
4. Refresh token when expired

### Client Credentials Flow
1. Request token with client_id and client_secret
2. Validate token response format
3. Use token for API requests

### Token Validation
1. Validate Bearer token on API requests
2. Return 401 for missing token
3. Return 401 for invalid token
4. Return 401 for expired token

### Token Response Format
\`\`\`json
{
  "access_token": "eyJ...",
  "token_type": "Bearer",
  "expires_in": 3600,
  "refresh_token": "...",
  "scope": "https://org.crm.dynamics.com/.default"
}
\`\`\`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Tests fail with "not implemented"
- OAuth flows match Azure AD behavior
- Token format matches specification

```typescript
// Using Secrets Store binding
```

title: GREEN: Add missing strict tsconfig options
description:
The packages/do/tsconfig.json has good strict settings but is missing some additional strict options that would catch more type errors.

Current settings (good):
- strict: true
- noUnusedLocals: true
- noUnusedParameters: true
- noImplicitReturns: true
- noFallthroughCasesInSwitch: true

Missing recommended options:
```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strictNullChecks": true,        // Already enabled by strict
    "noUncheckedIndexedAccess": true, // Missing - catches array/object indexing issues
    "exactOptionalPropertyTypes": true, // Missing - stricter optional property handling
    "noPropertyAccessFromIndexSignature": true, // Missing - forces bracket notation for index signatures
    "noImplicitOverride": true       // Missing - requires override keyword
  }
}
```

Benefits of additional options:
1. `noUncheckedIndexedAccess`: Prevents assuming array elements or object keys exist
   ```typescript
   const arr = [1, 2, 3]
   // Without: arr[5] is number
   // With: arr[5] is number | undefined
   ```

2. `exactOptionalPropertyTypes`: Prevents assigning undefined explicitly to optional properties
   ```typescript
   interface Foo { bar?: string }
   // Without: { bar: undefined } is valid
   // With: { bar: undefined } is invalid
   ```

3. `noImplicitOverride`: Requires explicit override keyword when overriding base class methods

title: rewrites/teradata - AI-Native MPP Warehouse
description: Teradata reimagined as an AI-native MPP warehouse. Durable Objects as AMPs, hash-distributed parallel execution, bi-temporal tables, workload management.
design:
## Architecture Mapping

| Teradata | Cloudflare |
|----------|------------|
| AMPs | DOs (hash-sharded) |
| PEs | Edge Workers |
| BYNET | DO RPC + Service Bindings |
| Vprocs | DO partitions |
| Data Dictionary | Iceberg catalog |
| Spool Space | DO SQLite temp |
| Fallback Tables | Multi-DO replication |

## Key Insight
Teradata's MPP maps beautifully to DOs:
- Each DO is an AMP
- Hash distribution via DO naming
- Parallel execution via concurrent DO calls
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] AMPDO with hash-based sharding
- [ ] Parallel query coordinator
- [ ] Bi-temporal table support
- [ ] Workload management agents
- [ ] Teradata SQL compatibility
- [ ] SDK at teradata.do

title: GREEN: Add typed SQLite query helpers for DO storage
close_reason:
Implemented typed SQLite query helpers for DO storage with the following components:

1. **StorageHelpers interface and implementation** - Provides type-safe query methods:
   - `query<T>()` - Returns Promise<T[]>
   - `queryOne<T>()` - Returns Promise<T | undefined>
   - `queryOneOrThrow<T>()` - Returns Promise<T> (throws on not found)
   - `queryCursor<T>()` - Returns AsyncIterable<T>
   - `queryWithMeta<T>()` - Returns result with metadata (rowsRead, rowsWritten, columnNames)
   - `execute()` - For mutations (returns Promise<void>)

2. **TypedQuery builder** - Fluent interface for building typed queries:
   - `.where()` - Add WHERE clauses
   - `.orderBy()` - Add ORDER BY with type-safe column names
   - `.limit()` - Add LIMIT
   - `.select<K>()` - Narrow to specific columns with Pick<T, K> return type
   - `.execute()` and `.executeOne()` - Execute with full type safety

3. **TypedRow utility type** - Maps SQL column types to TypeScript types

4. **Error types** - QueryError and ValidationError for proper error handling

5. **wrapTypedResult()** - Utility to wrap SqlStorageCursor with type safety

All 45 tests pass. The implementation eliminates the unsafe `.toArray() as T[]` pattern by providing properly typed query helpers.

title: GREEN: Add exhaustive switch checks for discriminated unions
description:
The codebase has switch statements on union types that lack exhaustive checks, meaning new union members could be missed at compile time.

Locations needing exhaustive checks:
1. packages/do/src/mcp/index.ts:432 - switch on toolName
2. packages/do/src/mcp/index.ts:467 - switch on toolName  
3. packages/do/src/sandbox/index.ts:225 - switch on environment
4. packages/do/src/storage.ts:1069 - switch on granularity

Current pattern (unsafe):
```typescript
switch (toolName) {
  case 'search': ...
  case 'fetch': ...
  case 'do': ...
  default:  // Just falls through or throws generic error
    throw new Error('Unknown tool')
}
```

Recommended pattern with exhaustive check:
```typescript
// Helper for exhaustive switch checks
function assertNever(value: never): never {
  throw new Error(`Unexpected value: ${value}`)
}

switch (toolName) {
  case 'search': ...
  case 'fetch': ...
  case 'do': ...
  default:
    assertNever(toolName)  // Compile error if union member not handled
}
```

This ensures that when new union members are added, TypeScript will report a compile-time error if they're not handled in the switch.

Add the `assertNever` helper to packages/do/src/utils/index.ts and use it across all switch statements on union types.

title: [RED] MedicationRequest resource search endpoint tests
description:
Write failing tests for the FHIR R4 MedicationRequest search endpoint.

## Test Cases - Search by Patient
1. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12742400 returns medication requests for patient
2. Patient parameter is required unless _id is provided

## Test Cases - Search by ID
3. GET /MedicationRequest?_id=313757847 returns specific medication request
4. _id cannot be combined with other params except _revinclude

## Test Cases - Search by Status
5. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&status=active returns active medications
6. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&status=completed returns completed medications
7. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&status=active,completed supports comma-separated list
8. Valid statuses: active, on-hold, cancelled, completed, entered-in-error, stopped, draft, unknown

## Test Cases - Search by Intent
9. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&intent=order returns orders
10. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&intent=plan returns plans
11. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&intent=order,plan supports comma-separated
12. Valid intents: proposal, plan, order, original-order, reflex-order, filler-order, instance-order, option

## Test Cases - Search by LastUpdated
13. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&_lastUpdated=ge2014-05-19T20:54:02.000Z returns updated after
14. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&_lastUpdated=ge2014-05-19&_lastUpdated=le2014-05-20 returns range
15. Supports prefixes: ge, le

## Test Cases - Search by Timing
16. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&-timing-boundsPeriod=ge2014-05-19 returns by dosage timing
17. -timing-boundsPeriod must use ge prefix

## Test Cases - Pagination
18. GET /MedicationRequest?patient=12345&_count=50 limits results per page
19. Response includes Link next when more pages available

## Test Cases - Provenance

21. Requires user/Provenance.read scope

## Response Shape
```json
{
  "resourceType": "Bundle",

  "total": 1,
  "entry": [
    {
      "fullUrl": "https://fhir.example.com/r4/MedicationRequest/313757847",

        "dosageInstruction": [...]
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

title: Create @dotdo/types package with consolidated type definitions
description:
Create a new `types/` folder at root level (published as `@dotdo/types`) that consolidates:

1. **Core utility types**: TaggedCallable, ExtractParams (generic callable pattern for fn(args), fn`template`, fn`{named}`(params))
2. **RPC types**: RpcPromise, RpcStub, RpcTarget from CapnWeb for promise pipelining
3. **DO infrastructure**: DOState, DOStorage, DOEnv, SqlStorage, SqlStorageCursor
4. **SQL template types**: Sql (TaggedCallable<SqlResult>), SqlResult
5. **Re-exports from primitives**: ai-functions, ai-workflows, ai-database, digital-workers, autonomous-agents, human-in-the-loop

Key design decisions:
- Flat .ts files (no src/ folder)
- Re-export from primitives + add workers.do-specific extensions
- TaggedCallable pattern supports: fn(args), fn`${val}`, fn`{name}`(params)
- RpcPromise enables promise pipelining (chain methods without awaiting)
close_reason: Implemented @dotdo/types package with: TaggedCallable, ExtractParams, RpcPromise, Sql types, DO types, and re-exports from primitives. Also implemented SQL proxy in sdks/rpc.do for transforming tagged templates to RPC-serializable format.

title: GREEN: XSS Prevention implementation passes tests
description:
Fix Monaco Editor XSS vulnerability by properly escaping HTML output.

## Solution
Use proper HTML escaping for all user-controlled data:

```typescript
function escapeHtml(str: string): string {
  return str
    .replace(/&/g, '&')
    .replace(/</g, '<')
    .replace(/>/g, '>')
    .replace(/"/g, '"')
    .replace(/'/g, ''')
}

// Or use Hono's html helper
import { html } from 'hono/html'
```

## Files
- `src/do.ts:2947-3008` - Monaco HTML generation
close_reason: All 40 XSS prevention tests pass. Implemented: encodeHtmlEntities, decodeHtmlEntities, detectScriptTags, escapeScriptTags, sanitizeEventHandlers, isValidUrl, isJavaScriptUrl, sanitizeUrl, generateCspHeader, createCspNonce

title: GREEN: SQL Injection prevention implementation passes tests
description:
Implement the fix to prevent SQL injection in DO.list() orderBy field.

## Solution
1. Create an allowlist of valid column names for orderBy
2. Validate orderBy against the allowlist before query execution
3. Reject any input containing SQL keywords or special characters
4. Use parameterized queries where possible

```typescript
const VALID_ORDER_COLUMNS = ['id', 'created_at', 'updated_at', 'collection'] as const
type ValidOrderColumn = typeof VALID_ORDER_COLUMNS[number]

function validateOrderBy(field: string): ValidOrderColumn {
  if (!VALID_ORDER_COLUMNS.includes(field as ValidOrderColumn)) {
    throw new Error(`Invalid orderBy field: ${field}`)
  }
  return field as ValidOrderColumn
}
```

## Files
- `src/do.ts` - DO.list() method
close_reason: Duplicate - using workers-t7x5 as GREEN issue

title: Cerner FHIR R4 API Compatibility
description:
Implement Cloudflare Workers-compatible Cerner/Oracle Health FHIR R4 API that mirrors the Oracle Health Millennium Platform APIs. This enables healthcare applications to interact with a local FHIR server that behaves identically to the production Cerner APIs.

## Scope
- SMART on FHIR OAuth 2.0 authorization (user, patient, system personas)
- Patient resource (read, search with name/identifier/birthdate/gender)
- Encounter resource (read, search by patient/date/status)
- Observation resource (read, search with category/code/date, vitals and labs)
- MedicationRequest resource (read, search by patient/status/intent)
- Bundle pagination and Link headers
- FHIR R4 content negotiation (application/fhir+json)

## API Reference
- Oracle Health FHIR R4: https://docs.oracle.com/en/industries/health/millennium-platform-apis/mfrap/r4_overview.html
- Authorization Framework: https://docs.oracle.com/en/industries/health/millennium-platform-apis/fhir-authorization-framework/
- Open Sandbox: https://fhir-open.cerner.com/r4/ec2458f2-1e24-41c8-b71b-0e701af7583d/

title: Implement OAuth token retrieval from Claude Code CLI
description:
Add ability to get a long-lived OAuth token from the Claude Code CLI for workers.do authentication.

**Use Case:**
Users authenticated with Claude Code CLI should be able to retrieve their OAuth token to use with workers.do SDKs without needing to re-authenticate.

**Commands:**
```bash
# Get token from Claude Code CLI
workers.do auth token
workers.do auth token --export    # Export as env var

# Or directly from Claude Code
claude auth token --for workers.do
```

**Integration:**
- Read from Claude Code's stored credentials
- Exchange for workers.do-specific token if needed
- Store in id.org.ai for persistence
- Set as DO_API_KEY environment variable

**Related:**
- id.org.ai OAuth flow
- WorkOS integration
- CLI authentication

title: RED: any type tests verify packages/do/src safety
description:
## Type Test Contract

Create type-level tests that fail when `any` types are present in packages/do/src.

## Test Strategy
```typescript
// tests/types/no-any.test.ts
import { expectTypeOf } from 'vitest';

// These should cause compile errors if any types leak
type AssertNoAny<T> = T extends any ? (any extends T ? never : T) : T;

// Test that exported types don't contain any
type DoContextType = typeof import('@dotdo/do').DO.prototype.ctx;
type AssertCtxNoAny = AssertNoAny<DoContextType>;  // Should fail if any
```

## Expected Failures
- Compile-time errors for any types
- tsd tests fail on unsafe patterns
- ESLint @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any violations

## Test Cases
1. All exported types must not contain `any`
2. All function parameters must have specific types
3. All return types must be explicit (no implicit any)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Type tests created using tsd or vitest type testing
- [ ] Tests fail on current codebase (RED state)
- [ ] ESLint rule @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any enabled
- [ ] All `any` locations documented
close_reason: RED phase complete: ESLint any type tests exist at packages/do-core/test/lint-as-any-ctx-access.test.ts. File produces 5 @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any errors as expected, demonstrating the problematic patterns that need to be fixed in GREEN phase.

title: Cascading Relationships System (->, ~>, <~, <-)
description:
Implement automatic cascading relationships for Durable Objects using intuitive operators:

- `->` Forward hard cascade (sync, blocking)
- `~>` Forward soft cascade (async, eventual)
- `<~` Reverse soft cascade (async, eventual)  
- `<-` Reverse hard cascade (sync, blocking)

This enables declarative relationship management across DOs without manual coordination.

title: [RED] Test ticket status transitions (new->open->pending->solved->closed)
description:
Write failing tests for ticket status state machine matching Zendesk behavior.

## Zendesk Status Values
- `new` - Initial state, no agent response yet
- `open` - Agent working on ticket
- `pending` - Awaiting customer response
- `hold` - On hold (internal)
- `solved` - Marked resolved, can reopen
- `closed` - Permanently closed, cannot modify

## Valid Transitions (from Zendesk docs)
- new -> open, pending, hold, solved
- open -> pending, hold, solved
- pending -> open, hold, solved
- hold -> open, pending, solved
- solved -> open (reopen)
- closed -> (no transitions, terminal state)

## Test Cases
1. Valid transition: new -> open succeeds
2. Invalid transition: new -> closed fails
3. Closed tickets reject all updates
4. solved -> open reopening works
5. Status change updates updated_at timestamp
acceptance_criteria:
- Tests for all valid transitions
- Tests for invalid transitions returning 422
- Tests verify closed is terminal
- Tests verify timestamp updates on status change
